Award.AwardTitle: Mechanically Controlled Polymerization via Piezo-reduction of Copper
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plastics, a form of polymeric materials, break down after repeated use. One of the causes of this break-down is the rupture of chemical bonds of the polymers. Professor Esser-Kahn examines methods of using force or pressure to generate new bonds in plastic materials. These materials will be capable of capturing energy from an applied force or pressure and using it to initiate the growth of a polymer chain or the formation of a polymer network to strengthen the material. This project includes research and educational components to impact fundamental knowledge about polymer materials across the disciplines of chemistry and engineering. Outreach entails summer research training of high-school interns.

Jointly supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry and the Polymer Program of the Division of Materials Research, the Esser-Kahn research group is developing novel approaches that use the reaction of piezo-electric particles as a method to generate new bonds in polymeric materials. In one direction, the project investigates the piezo-reduction of a Cu(II) precursor to a Cu(I) activator that initiates the growth of polymer chain via atom-transfer radical polymerization. In a second direction, the piezo-generated Cu(I) is used to catalyze azide-alkyne cyclo-addition, creating new bonds between click chemistry handles. The research activities include 1) generation of novel reactions using piezo-mechanical reduction, 2) the growth of new polymer chains and types using piezo-ATRP, 3) the crosslinking of polymer gels using piezo-electric reactivity; and 4) the study and development of piezo-responsive materials and their mechanical characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological materials display great adaptability to their environment, as is the case of bones, muscles and skin which can adapt in response to mechanical stimuli by changing their composition and structure through a process called mechanotransduction. They efficiently convert mechanical stimuli into chemical signals that can drive reactions leading to structural changes, deposition and removal of material. These adaptive properties give them great advantage in terms of efficiency and durability. Currently, synthetic polymeric materials mostly lack similar adaptability, resulting in mismatches in their physical properties and the need to replace them repeatedly. Significant effort has been devoted in designing novel chemical systems which impart synthetic polymers with self-reporting and self-healing properties. Several reports have shown the use of heat, light, electricity, pH and pressure changes to mediate the identification of a failure in polymeric material, deposition of new material, or the formation of new chemical bonds. However, few mechanically responsive systems that target adaptation of the material have been developed. Recently, we have investigated methods to use mechanical energy in combination with the piezoelectrochemical effect to conduct controlled chain-growth, step-growth and crosslinking polymerization reactions.

 

Piezoelectricity offered a unique approach to convert mechanical stimuli into chemical energy by creating redox micro-environments within a polymer matrix. Our project has focused on using mechanical energy to activate piezoelectric nanoparticles and subsequently initiate or promote polymerization reactions. In our first study, we demonstrated that ultrasonic agitation of piezoelectric BaTiO3 nanoparticles could promote atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) of acrylate monomers by reducing a Cu(II) complex to Cu(I) polymerization promoters. Subsequently, others showed that ATRP is compatible with other monomers and other ceramic piezoelectric nanoparticles, namely ZnO. In a follow up work, we developed a mechanically activated polymerization mediated by the copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC), commonly known as copper ‘click’ reaction. The study showed a step-growth polymerization via ultrasound promoted copper ‘click’ reaction to form a linear polytriazole, as well as crosslinking of a linear polyurethane with ‘click’ handles. It was the first example of gel formation via piezo-polymerization. In addition, we expanded our original methodology to include free-radical polymerization of various acrylates using Fe catalyst and ZnO nanoparticles as activators.

 

In an effort to expand the repertoire of piezo-polymerization reactions beyond metal catalysts, we looked into fully organic transformations. In our most recent work, we showed that ZnO nanoparticles, under mechanical agitation, can promote a step-growth linear polymerization and gel formation via the thiol-ene reaction. Furthermore, we developed an electrodynamic shaking system to apply mechanical waves with low frequency (1-2000 Hz) and amplitude, as opposed to our original system of ultrasonic agitation (40 kHz). Under these milder sonication conditions, we achieved the mechanically-promoted strengthening of a methyl cellulose organogel via thiol-ene crosslinking reaction. Preliminary studies coupled with computational models showed a heterogenous distribution of mechanical properties (elastic modulus) throughout the gel. This indicated that it is possible to form distinct gelation patterns within the solid by changing its morphology and the distribution of the mechanical waves.

 

Our current goals include investigating the mechanism of thiol activation via the piezoelectrochemical effect, expanding on the types of composite materials that can be strengthened with this methodology, and exploring alternative piezo-polymerization reactions to expand the repertoire of materials that can be reinforced.
